unit which in 2003, fentanyl had just finished

Hiolski: The illicit use of synthetic opioids
like fentanyl is nothing new in Baltimore.

In the current crisis, however, these drugs
are more pervasive than ever before.
Pitts: Now what we're seeing is a steady pace of fentanyl cases in all different types.
So you might get a case that is just fentanyl.

You might get a case where it's fentanyl and

You might get a case where it's fentanyl and

I had fentanyl and ketamine recently.
To us they're just throwing stuff together

Some of the mixtures we've seen will kill

Hiolski: These lethal and unprecedented mixtures
are forcing forensic chemists to face new
challenges and dangers.

To learn about those, we visited Monique Pitts
of the Drug Analysis Unit at the Baltimore
Police Department.

Pitts: Right now we don't really have any
good preliminary test for fentanyl.
But we also want to minimize everyone's exposure.
So we take safety precautions with everything.

We try not to even open the packages very
much anymore.

Or we use our hoods all the time, everyone
wears masks.
We assume fentanyl is everything now.

Hiolski: Previously, chemists could use quick
and simple test reactions that changed color

or produced a precipitate to get some idea
of what’s in a sample.

With more potent drug samples coming into
Pitts’ lab now, taking multiple samples
for those tests puts analysts at greater risk.

At the U.S. National Institute for Standards
& Technology, Jennifer Verkouteren and Ed

Sisco are working to vet analytical tools
that could help replace those rapid, preliminary tests.

But that process takes times and Verkouteren
is still concerned about the demand shouldered

by people on the front line of the opioid
crisis.

Verkouteren: Everything gets treated as if
it could be very dangerous.

And so they can't sort of triage and say okay
it's only these materials that we have to
be very concerned about.
And I think that probably will lead to problems with fatigue.
You simply can't go day to day to day treating everything as if it’s a chemical warfare agent.

Emma: Although Pitts and her colleagues don’t
rely on preliminary tests anymore, they can

still trust their more powerful analytical
instruments to identify unknown compounds.
Pitts: The GC-MS.
Gas chromatograph-mass spectrometer.
Old faithful.
The FTIR,
if it's a purer sample.
Yeah, the GC-MS is pretty good.
Yeah.

Hiolski: The trade off is that these tools
require more time and sample prep than the
old preliminary tests.

But with improved safety protocols, Pitts
and her team are prepared to continue doing
their jobs until technology catches up.

Pitts: We always need more resources, but
the main thing for us to continue to get more
safety procedures in place.

As the global market for illicit drugs grows,
it's just going to get way more complicated.

So we just have to continue with what we're
doing and, like I said, put in for more instruments, more
people and we'll see what happens.
